content.body: annevk (or anyone else who loves answering questions about the URL spec): Not part of a conforming ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#absolute-url-string can never contain any ASCII whitespace, right?
content.formatted_body: annevk (or anyone else who loves answering questions about the URL spec): Not part of a conforming ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#absolute-url-string can never contain any ASCII whitespace, right?

content.body: Context is, I‚Äôm working on implementing the constraint-validation requirements for `type=url` `input` elements. And I‚Äôm hoping to avoid needing to write an actual lexer for ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù ‚Äî¬†and instead just actually run the URL parser on the URLs, with some preprocessing and post-processing
content.formatted_body: Context is, I‚Äôm working on implementing the constraint-validation requirements for type=url input elements. And I‚Äôm hoping to avoid needing to write an actual lexer for ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù ‚Äî and instead just actually run the URL parser on the URLs, with some preprocessing and post-processing

content.body: And it _seems_ like one pre-processing step that‚Äôd work is to return not-valid for any strings that contain ASCII whitespace
content.formatted_body: And it seems like one pre-processing step that‚Äôd work is to return not-valid for any strings that contain ASCII whitespace

content.body: hmm, given that in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/input.html#url-state-(type=url), the spec specifically and normatively references [‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù](https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#syntax-url-absolute) and _not_ [‚Äúabsolute-URL-*with-fragment* string‚Äù](https://url.spec.whatwg.org/#absolute-url-with-fragment-string), then that means: if a URL has any fragment at all, then the requirement is that implementations much handle it as an invalid value for `type=url` `input` element (for the purposes of the constraint-validation API)?
content.formatted_body: hmm, given that in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/input.html#url-state-(type=url), the spec specifically and normatively references ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù and not ‚Äúabsolute-URL-with-fragment string‚Äù, then that means: if a URL has any fragment at all, then the requirement is that implementations much handle it as an invalid value for type=url input element (for the purposes of the constraint-validation API)?

content.body: I am 95% sure browsers do not implement that...
well that‚Äôs the thing
I am implementing it
Attempting to ‚Äî per the actual spec requirements
So if the requirements don‚Äôt actually match what other implementors are interested in, then I guess we need to update the spec
But yeah you‚Äôre right ‚Äî other engines don‚Äôt implement it per-spec
And I have not looked at their code, but I strongly suspect that one big reason is that no existing implementations are actually running a lexer to check that ‚Äúabsolute-URL string‚Äù requirement
Instead, they‚Äôre probably all just parsing the value into a URL, and only returning invalid if they don‚Äôt get any URL value back from that

At least I can see that seems to be the case from the tests I‚Äôve run so far¬†‚Äî¬†with some dozens of cases from https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/275544eab54a0d0c7f74ccc2baae9711293d8908/url/urltestdata.txt

I‚Äôd be happy to just make my implementation match what other engines are doing, and add a comment in our code saying that. But then, we also rightly should have many more tests in WPT for this. And I have tests I can upstream. But if I make the test results match what other engines are doing, then those tests are not actually going to be conforming to the spec requirements‚Ä¶

The existing test for this in WPT at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/6618dc6e2a580d6d816f7a5b291c016f7a2c0204/html/semantics/forms/constraints/form-validation-checkValidity.html#L30 has exactly one case: the string `abc`
content.formatted_body: The existing test for this in WPT at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/6618dc6e2a580d6d816f7a5b291c016f7a2c0204/html/semantics/forms/constraints/form-validation-checkValidity.html#L30 has exactly one case: the string abc

content.body: Yeah, I'm just saying if it were me, I would drop implementation work and instead open a spec issue to get this sorted.
ah OK yeah there‚Äôs plenty of other stuff we need that I can work on the meantime
(but when I started out on implementing this, it looked to me (na√Øvely) like it was going to be relatively low-hanging fruit‚Ä¶))
Made a WPT PR at https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/51011/files with the added tests
Do we currently have a way of hosting/enabling people to run WPT tests from a PR branch?
I kind of vaguely recall seeing something a while back. Like, with w3c-test.org (predecessor to wpt.live) we used to have a thing that created subdirectories for every pull request
I think there might be an existing issue on type=url. It needs something similar to type=email work.
ah OK, I‚Äôll look now
Well, didn‚Äôt find it yet. Not in whatwg/html at least
sideshowbarker: can't find it either, please file one? Non-ASCII input in various parts of the URL would also be good to test. Including what ends up getting submitted.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: can't find it either, please file one? Non-ASCII input in various parts of the URL would also be good to test. Including what ends up getting submitted.

content.body: We should adopt a policy that anybody who abandons a spec ‚Äî or neglects/leaves it unmaintained over N number of months/years¬†‚Äî is barred for life from ever being able to write another spec
